questions.text: A patient presented with shortness of breath and a dry cough. His spirometry test shows a restrictive pattern. The HRCT scan is shown below. Which of the following would you expect to find in the physical examination of this patient?

choices.text: Stony dull note note on percussion

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath and dry cough, spirometry showing a restrictive defect points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. The given HRCT shows prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones, likely to be idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). The patient will have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options :

Option A: Bronchial breath sounds are heard in patients with consolidation, such as in pneumonia. The sound from the airways is conducted to the skin better when the alveoli are consolidated. This leads to bronchial breath sounds.

Option C: Barrel-shaped chest is associated with emphysema. This occurs because of the loss of the parenchymal elastic tissue in the lung, leading to hyperinflation.

Option D: Stony dull note on percussion is seen in pleural effusion.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with cough, dyspnea, fever, and fatigue. On examination, inspiratory rales are present. A high-resolution CT image is given below. The lung biopsy showed characteristic Masson bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with cough, dyspnoea, fever, HRCT image showing characteristic reversed halo sign, and biopsy showing Masson bodies points to a probable diagnosis of cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) is idiopathic interstitial pneumonia that typically involves elderly patients. It usually presents as mild flu-illness with fever, cough, and dyspnoea. On auscultation, inspiratory rales are usually present.

This disease can be sporadic or can also occur secondary to conditions such as connective tissue disorders (polymyositis) and malignancy.

High-resolution CT (HRCT) is the preferred imaging modality of choice. Patchy consolidation with a predominantly subpleural and/or peribronchial distribution is the most common finding. Some cases are associated with ground-glass opacity or crazy paving pattern. The characteristic reverse halo sign or atoll sign is highly specific but is seen in a few cases.


Histologically, COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and bronchioles, with foci of fibrosis. There is no interstitial fibrosis or honeycombing of the lung.


Treatment:

Corticosteroids provide substantial remission and are usually required to be continued for at least 6 months to avoid relapses. Cytotoxic (mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide) or biologic (rituximab) therapies can be helpful in both treating the disease and reducing the need for steroids.

Other options: 

Option A: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is the most common form of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia. It is a progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown etiology occurring in adults and is associated with the histological or radiological pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

HRCT shows a patchy, predominantly peripheral, subpleural and basal reticular pattern. In advanced cases, honeycombing cysts and traction bronchiectasis may be present.

UIP has a poor prognosis and is generally refractive to treatment.

The below CT scan shows interstitial thickening, architectural distortion, honeycombing and bronchiectasis as seen in UIP.


Option B: Non-specific interstitial pneumonia is characterized by bilateral, subpleural, symmetrical ground glass reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis. In contrast to UIP, honeycombing is uncommon and has a better prognosis. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis, but not as common as the UIP pattern. Management includes steroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, and rituximab with pulmonary rehabilitation.

Option D: Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities. Histologically AIP presents histopathologically as diffuse alveolar damage. It is associated with high mortality.

questions.text: A patient underwent lung transplant due to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis 2 years ago. Over the past 7 months, he has had a progressive decrease in pulmonary function on serial spirometry. A biopsy shows lymphocytic infiltrate and fibrosed airways. What is this pattern of rejection called?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of lung transplantation with progressively worsening pulmonary function suggests chronic graft rejection. The biopsy findings of a lymphocytic infiltrate with fibrosed airways are typical of bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome(BOS). 

BOS is the classic form of lung rejection and more than 50% of patients who receive a lung transplant will develop it to some extent in 5 years. It is characterised by breathlessness and cough that develops after months to years after a transplant. There should be persistence of symptoms for more than 3 weeks and other causes of graft dysfunction should be excluded.

Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy which shows the lymphocytic infiltrate and fibrosis of the terminal airways with alveolar sparing.  A CT scan shows fibrosis and thickening of the bronchial walls and a mosaic pattern persists due to air trapping. 

Treatment is by augmentation of immunosuppression as the disease course is thought to be a form of organ rejection. 

Other Options:

Acute cellular rejection occurs within days to weeks of a transplant. This patient has had the symptoms 2 years after the transplant. 

Vanishing airway syndrome also called vanishing bronchus syndrome presents post-transplant with necrotic changes in the walls of the bronchus. It is very rare and is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms. 

Graft versus host disease rarely involves the lungs and is unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A patient presenting with breathing difficulties is a known case of tuberous sclerosis. Later on, the patient is diagnosed with lymphangioleiomyomatosis. This pulmonary condition has a predilection for which epidemiological parameters?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) has a predilection for non-smoker, female patients.

It is usually seen in young females with tuberous sclerosis. LAM can lead to pneumothorax or chylous effusions. 

Pulmonary function testing usually reveals an obstructive or mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern. HRCT shows thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. 

Smoking-related ILDs:

  • DIP - Desquamative interstitial pneumonia.
  • RB-ILD - Respiratory bronchiolitis–associated ILD
  • LCH - Langerhans cell histiocytosis

Sex predilection in ILDs

Women Men
Pulmonary LAM (associated with tuberous sclerosis) Pneumoconiosis (due to occupational exposure to asbestos, beryllium, and silica)
ILDs associated with connective tissue disorder (CTD) (except ILD associated with rheumatoid arthritis) ILD associated with rheumatoid arthritis 
  Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)
  Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH)

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, dry cough, and dyspnea on exertion. On examination, his hands showed hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint. Laboratory results revealed normocytic normochromic anemia and elevated anti-CCP antibodies. What is the most common interstitial lung disease associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and blood picture in the scenario suggest rheumatoid arthritis. The most common interstitial lung disease associated with this condition is usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

Laboratory diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein.
  • Serum rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody (anti-CCP) are positive. Anti-CCP antibodies are more specific for diagnosis and a predictor of poor prognosis.
  • The most common anemia associated is normocytic normochromic anemia.

Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint suggest swan neck deformity in rheumatoid arthritis. UIP has a poor prognosis and is generally refractive to treatment.

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) is the initial investigation of choice for a patient with interstitial lung disease. The most common HRCT pattern seen in a patient with ILD in rheumatoid arthritis is the UIP pattern. Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) can also be seen. The characteristic HRCT findings of UIP are - 

  • Bilateral, lower lobe, subpleural reticular changes
  • Traction bronchiectasis
  • Honey combing pattern

The image given below shows the CT findings of UIP:


Option B - Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) is characterized by bilateral, subpleural, symmetrical ground glass reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis. In contrast to UIP, honeycombing is uncommon and has a better prognosis. This pattern is universally found in patients with systemic sclerosis. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but is not as common as the UIP pattern. Management includes steroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, and rituximab with pulmonary rehabilitation.

Option C - Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) shows patchy subpleural consolidative opacities. A characteristic peribronchiolar/ perilobar opacities with a rim of subpleural sparing called the reverse halo sign is seen. COP is commonly mistaken for pneumonia and can present secondary to polymyositis.

 The image given below shows the reversed halo sign:


Option D - Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities. It is associated with high mortality.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Which of the following patients will have predominantly fibrosis of upper lobes of the lung?

choices.text: A 25 year old man with  bleomycin use
A 45 year old woman with scleroderma
A 55 year old man with asbestosis
A 35 year old woman with sarcoidosis

questions.solution:
A 35-year-old woman with sarcoidosis is the most likely to have fibrosis of the upper lobes of the lung.

Note: Most pneumoconiosis involves the upper lobes of the lung (coal worker's pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis), except asbestosis.

Most connective tissue disease predominantly involves the lower lobes of the lung (RA, scleroderma, SLE), except for ankylosing spondylitis. The use of bleomycin also causes lower lobe fibrosis. 

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

Mnemonic to easily remember the lobe of lung involved in CTD is:

Upper Lobe - CHARTS

  • Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis
  • Histiocytosis X (LCH)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis, ABPA
  • Radiation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Lower lobes - RAIDS

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Asbestosis
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding non-specific interstitial pneumonia?

choices.text: Usually affects females who have never smoked

questions.solution:
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) responds to steroids. Other treatment modalities include cytotoxic drugs like azathioprine or cyclophosphamide and also biologics like rituximab.

It is often associated with connective tissue disease but can also be drug-induced. The common drugs implicated in NSIP are:

  • Bleomycin
  • Busulfan
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Methotrexate
  • Amiodarone

It usually affects middle-aged females who have never smoked. HRCT shows homogenous involvement with symmetrical ground-glass opacities.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman presented with gradually increasing shortness of breath over the past 6 months. Examination reveals finger clubbing and bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function test showed a restrictive defect with reduced lung volumes. HRCT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath, finger clubbing, and fine inspiratory crackles, spirometry showing a restrictive defect and reduced lung volumes points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. In the given HRCT, there is prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones. This is seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options:

Option A: Acute interstitial pneumonia is characterized by a sudden onset of hypoxemia and respiratory distress, following symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection. HRCT shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities and consolidation of the air spaces.

Options B and D: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated with ILD (RB-ILD) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) are more commonly seen in smokers. HRCT shows prominent ground-glass opacities in both these disorders.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old male patient came with complaints of difficulty in breathing, cough, fatigue, and malaise for a few months. His sputum was chunky, gelatinous, and PAS-positive. A histological specimen of the lung is given below. The above condition is caused by autoantibodies against the function of _______.

PAS: Periodic acid–schiff 

GM-CSF: Granulocyte-macrophage - colony stimulating factor
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of dyspnea, cough with chunky, gelatinous, PAS-positive sputum, and histological specimen of lung showing alveoli filled with pink, dense, homogeneous, amorphous material with the intact alveolar wall are suggestive of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)which is caused by autoantibodies against the function of granulocyte- macrophage-colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF).

PAP is an interstitial lung disease caused by defect in the function of pulmonary macrophages. This is due to reduced signaling of GM-CSF which results in the accumulation of surfactants in the intra-alveolar and bronchiolar spaces. Surfactant proteins can be demonstrated by immunohistochemical stains. It is predominantly seen in adults. They present with progressive dyspnoea, cough with sputum containing gelatinous, chunky PAS-positive material. It can be associated with clubbing and cyanosis. On radiological examination, asymmetric patchy opacifications mainly on the hilar regions of both lungs are seen. GM-CSF replacement therapy and whole-lung lavage are effective treatments. 

PAP is classified into 3 types:

Autoimmune PAP is due to the presence of circulating antibodies that bind and neutralize the function of GM-CSF. It primarily occurs in adults and this represents 90% of all cases. Autoimmune PAP lacks familial predisposition. 

Secondary PAP is due to the diverse diseases that impair the GM-CSF signaled macrophage function, leading to inadequate clearance of surfactant from alveolar spaces.

Hereditary PAP is due to GM-CSF and GM-CSF receptor gene mutations. This occurs in neonates and is extremely rare.

Other options:

Option A. Lecithin (dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine), Option B. protein A, Option C protein B are surfactants. The deficiency of these surfactants causes respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a two-week history of progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and fever. Physical examination shows diffuse crackles in both lungs. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated CRP. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral alveolar infiltrates and HRCT shows patchy ground glass opacities. There is no significant medical history or known exposures. What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Hamman-rich syndrome or acute interstitial pneumonia is the most likely diagnosis in this patient who has presented acutely with rapid onset of severe respiratory symptoms and HRCT findings of patchy ground glass opacities. 

Hamman-rich syndrome is a rare and frequently fatal lung disorder marked by the sudden onset of respiratory distress and hypoxemia. It often follows a prodromal period with symptoms similar to an acute upper respiratory infection. The mortality rate within six months of diagnosis is significant, exceeding 50%, and recurrences are common. Treatment is mostly supportive and includes mechanical ventilation.

Other options:

Option A: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: It presents chronically over months to years and shows a UIP pattern with honeycombing on HRCT

Option C: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: It is associated with known exposures to organic antigens and often shows centrilobular nodules and upper lobe predominance on imaging

Option D: Pneumocystis jeroveci pneumonia occurs in immunocompromised patients. Imaging might show ground-glass opacities but also often includes cysts or pneumothorax

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male complains of shortness of breath on exertion, associated with dry cough for the past 2 months. Examination reveals grade 3 clubbing and basal rales on auscultation. HRCT of the chest shows bilateral subpleural reticular changes, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing of the lung parenchyma. Which of the following flow-volume loops is expected to be seen in this patient?

High-Resolution Computed Tomogram - HRCT
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of an interstitial lung disease probably idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). The flow-volume loop, in this case, would be similar to that of image 4 which corresponds to a restrictive pattern of the flow-volume loop.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is usually seen in the fifth or sixth decade of life. Males are affected more than females. Clinical features include progressive dyspnoea more common with exertion, dry cough, and end-inspiratory crackles or rales on auscultation. Digital clubbing is seen. The HRCT findings include bilateral subpleural reticular changes, traction bronchiectasis, and honeycombing of the lung parenchyma.

questions.text:
A patient is diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following pharmacologic agents are indicated for treatment?
  1. Prednisone
  2. Nintedanib
  3. Azathioprine
  4. Cyclophosphamide
  5. Pirfenidone
questions.solution:
Pharmacologic treatments that are currently indicated for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis(IPF) include pirfenidone and nintedanib, which are antifibrotic agents.

Pirfenidone is approved by the FDA for the treatment of IPF. Pirfenidone works by inhibiting the production of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β), a key mediator of fibrosis. It has been shown to slow the decline in lung function and improve survival in patients with IPF.

Nintedanib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor also proven to be beneficial in IPF.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO which may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia pattern . Ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

Other options: 

Statements 1, 3, 4: Steroids and immunosuppressants are no longer indicated in the treatment of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, and have been associated with poorer outcomes.

questions.text: Pulmonary fibrosis is caused by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Drugs causing Pulmonary fibrosis include:

  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Methysergide
  • Amiodarone
  • Interferon
  • Bleomycin
  • Busulfan
  • Mitomycin

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of dry cough, dyspnea and chest x-ray showing the characteristic garland triad. Her pulmonary function test will most likely resemble which of the following curves?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient's symptoms of dry cough and dyspnea along with the chest x-ray showing the garland triad are characteristic of Sarcoidosis which shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve, represented by curve 4.   

Sarcoidosis presents with ventilatory restriction due to increased elastic recoil. It is characterized by a decrease in total lung capacity and vital capacity, hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts toward the right as seen in curve 4 in comparison to curve 1 which represents the normal flow-volume curve.

Increased flow occurs as the increased lung recoil drives greater maximal flow at any lung volume and also because airway diameters are relatively increased due to greater radially outward traction exerted on bronchi by the stiff lung parenchyma.  

In restrictive diseases, both FEV1 (Forced expiratory volume in the first second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) are reduced but FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or increased as FVC is reduced to a greater degree due to decreased compliance.

An FEV1/FVC ratio > 0.7 signifies restrictive lung disorder, whereas <0.7 is seen in obstructive diseases.

Curve 2 is an obstructive pattern of the flow-volume curve with a concave upward pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Curve 3 shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern, seen in tracheal stenosis. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration, leading to the flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop.

Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. The disease is often multisystemic and requires the presence of involvement in two or more organs for a specific diagnosis. Lungs are most commonly affected.

Respiratory complaints including cough and dyspnea are the most common presenting symptoms. In many cases, the patient presents with a 2- to 4-week history of these symptoms.

The characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement that is seen in this condition is known as the Garland triad or 1-2-3 sign or pawnbroker's sign. The lymph nodes involved are:

  1. Right paratracheal nodes
  2. Right hilar nodes
  3. Left hilar nodes

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who was a welder for the past 10 years presents with a dry cough, easy fatiguability, weight loss, and dyspnea progressing over the past 1 year. On examination, fine end-inspiratory crackles were heard over the bilateral infra-axillary regions. His HRCT finding is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The HRCT provided shows a characteristic crazy-paving pattern which is classical of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. 

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a lung disease involving the accumulation of surfactant within the alveoli as a result of decreased clearance. It may be congenital, secondary, or autoimmune.

Etiology:

  • Congenital
  • Secondary: due to lung infections, hematologic malignancies, and inhalation of mineral dust such as silica, titanium oxide, aluminum, indium-tin-oxide, and insecticides.
  • Autoimmune: autoantibodies against GM-CSF

Patients may have features like a persistent dry cough (or with scant sputum production), progressive dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, intermittent low-grade fever and/or night sweats, and pleuritic chest pain. Rarely, they may have cyanosis and hemoptysis. The physical examination will show fine end-inspiratory crackles. Clubbing and cyanosis may be present in a few cases.

Diagnosis is with bronchoscopic lavage and/or biopsy, along with imaging findings. Chest X-ray shows nonspecific findings with bilateral lung opacification. A batwing appearance may be seen.

The CT shows a characteristic ‘crazy-paving’ pattern. It refers to geographical areas of ground-glass opacification with thickened inter-and intralobular septa.

Treatment includes whole lung lavage and treatment of the underlying cause. GM-CSF replacement is considered if an underlying autoimmune etiology is suspected.

Other causes causing similar crazy-paving appearance:

  • Lipoid pneumonia
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia
  • Silicosis,
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A 30-year old chronic smoker presented with a history of dry cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and recurrent pneumothoraces over the past few months. An HRCT report showed multiple nodules and cysts. The lung biopsy appears as below. Which of the following is a characteristic electron microscopic finding for this disease?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathological image showing Langerhan cells with folded nuclei is suggestive of adult pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Birbeck granules are the characteristic election microscopy finding seen in this disease.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens. The most common mutation is BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)- The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad - mostly seen in older children, adults
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis - mostly seen in adults

Clinical features include:

  • Often asymptomatic
  • Dyspnea, cough, bone pain, an abnormal growth of soft tissue over the affected bone, rash, pruritus, increased thirst, and lymphadenopathy.
  • Fatigue, generalized weakness, weight loss, night sweats, nausea, and fever may also occur.

Histopathologically, Langerhans cells have a single large nucleus with a characteristic folded or grooved nucleus (coffee-bean appearance) with small inconspicuous nucleoli. Birbeck granules are seen in the cytoplasm. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhan cells with folded nuclei.

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket–like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy. The image below shows Birbeck granules on electron microscopy seen in LCH.

The below image shows lytic lesion of skull seen in LCH.

Diagnosis is confirmed by a biopsy of the lesion. Spontaneous regression is seen in asymptomatic lesions and after cessation of smoking in pulmonary LCH. Symptomatic cases are managed with intralesional steroid injection, low-dose radiotherapy, and curettage of the lesion. Multiagent chemotherapy is indicated for multisystemic disease.

 

Other options:

Rosenthal fibres are eosinophilic corkscrew-shaped inclusions seen in pilocytic astrocytomas.

Fried-egg appearance is seen in sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm seen in oligodendrogliomas.

Corps ronds are rounded dyskeratotic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm in the epidermis  seen in Darier's disease. Corps grains are small cells with shrunken cytoplasm, also seen in association with corps ronds.

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient working in the cement manufacturing industry presents with chronic cough and dyspnea. His chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic cough and dyspnea with the chest radiograph showing eggshell calcification of the hilar lymph nodes, a diagnosis of silicosis is the most likely.

Silicosis is the most common occupational lung disease in the world. Occupational exposures associated with silicosis include mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, glass and cement manufacturing, and quarrying of granite. The pathogenic form of silica is crystalline quartz. Inhaled silica crystals are phagocytosed by macrophages and cause the release of IL-1 and IL-18. This causes the recruitment of more inflammatory cells and fibroblasts to the site, leading to collagen deposition.

Silicosis can present in the following ways:

  • Acute silicosis occurs due to exposure to high concentrations of silica in closed spaces. Patients have clinical manifestations within a few months to years of exposure.
  • Chronic silicosis occurs due to long-term exposure to silica, often 10 to 30 years
  • Progressive massive fibrosis can occur following both acute and chronic silicosis. The patients present with more severe cough and dyspnea than simple silicosis, and might develop respiratory failure and cor pulmonale. 

Since silicosis leads to macrophage dysfunction, it increases the risk of tuberculosis in patients. Silica also has immunoadjuvant properties, and might lead to autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. Silica exposure is also considered to be a risk factor for lung cancer.

Calcification of hilar lymph nodes producing a characteristic eggshell pattern is seen in many cases of silicosis. The fibrotic areas present in the lung parenchyma can be identified on the HRCT of the lung. Acute silicosis may show diffuse ground-glass opacities with thickening of the interlobular septae, which is termed as crazy pavement appearance.

questions.text: A sugarcane farmer presents with dyspnea and cough for the last 3 weeks. HRCT shows bilateral ground glass opacities. Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the CD4+/CD8+ ratio is found to be < 1. Lung biopsy shows poorly formed noncaseating granulomas. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient with cough and dyspnea for the last 3 weeks, with ground glass opacities on HRCT, CD4+/CD8+ ratio < 1, and poorly formed granulomas on lung biopsy, the most likely diagnosis is hypersensitivity pneumonitis. 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) occurs due to inhalational exposure to a number of antigens, causing inflammation of the alveoli and the small airways. The cause of the inflammation is dysregulated Th1 and Th17 immune response (type IV hypersensitivity). 

HP has been divided into 3 forms depending on the clinical manifestations:

  1. Acute HP manifests within 8 hours of exposure to the antigen. The symptoms include fever with chills, malaise, and dyspnea. There is complete resolution of the symptoms within hours to days if there is no further exposure to the antigen. 
  2. In subacute HP, the systemic and pulmonary symptoms develop insidiously over a few weeks, like in this patient. Complete resolution of symptoms is seen here as well, but it takes a longer time. 
  3. Chronic HP presents with an even slower course — with cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and clubbing of digits. Unlike other forms, there is permanent impairment of the airways to some extent in chronic HP. This is irreversible and does not respond to the removal of inciting agents from the patient's environment. 

In subacute HP, HRCT shows ground glass opacities and centrilobular nodules. In chronic HP, subpleural honeycombing is seen, but unlike idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, there is sparing of the base of the lungs. Either obstructive or restrictive patterns may be seen on pulmonary function testing. Detection of IgG antibodies against specific antigens is an adjunctive investigation in the diagnosis of HP.

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage shows a CD4+/CD8+ lymphocyte ratio < 1 in most cases of HP. Lung biopsy shows the formation of noncaseating granulomas, but they are poorly defined.

The mainstay of treatment of HP is avoidance of the offending antigen. However, in subacute and chronic forms of the disease, there is a role of steroids as well. 

Other options:

Option A: A close differential in this case can be sarcoidosis. However, sarcoidosis is characterized by well-defined noncaseating granulomas, and CD4+/CD8+ ratio of >1 in BAL. Furthermore, the presence of a clear-cut risk factor in this patient makes the diagnosis more likely to be HP.

Option B: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis will not show granulomatous inflammation on lung biopsy. Furthermore, the HRCT findings in IPF include honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis. The presence of ground glass opacities is only transient, and extensive ground glass opacities should prompt an alternative diagnosis.

Option D: Tuberculosis will present as upper lobe infiltrates with cavitation on CT scan. The sputum smear microscopy will be positive for acid-fast bacilli and nucleic acid amplification test.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman diagnosed with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) 14 years back presents with breathlessness for a few months. Her PFT is as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis and the PFT showing an isolated decrease in DLCO suggest a diagnosis of pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH).

A PFT pattern showing near-normal FVC, increased FEV1, and decreased DLCO which is consistent with diffusion lung disease. The cause of diffusion lung disease can be due to both pulmonary hypertension and interstitial lung disease (ILD). But in this patient with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, pulmonary artery hypertension is the most likely etiologic factor.

Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is more strongly associated with the development of PAH than diffuse systemic sclerosis. However, diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis is associated more commonly with interstitial lung disease. In patients with ILD, FVC is usually <80% of the predicted value indicating restrictive pathology.

questions.text: A patient with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) presents for follow-up. He has a history of progressive dyspnea and dry cough for the past year. His FVC has declined by 10% from the previous year. You propose treatment with Pirfenidone. Which of the following statements regarding Pirfenidone is true?

choices.text: It is a bronchodilator that helps open up the airways.
It is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation in the airways.
It is an antifibrotic agent that slows down the progression of scarring.
It is an antibiotic that treats bacterial infections in the airway.

questions.solution:
Pirfenidone is approved by the FDA for the treatment of IPF. Pirfenidone works by inhibiting the production of transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β), a key mediator of fibrosis. It has been shown to slow the decline in lung function and improve survival in patients with IPF.

IPF is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.
